title: Is there a file listing Interface
description:
I try to implement a pyfilesystem2 implementation of IGitt.

For this I need to access branches and including files directly online.

Is there a function to get a filelist/urllist of files included in a repository?

Also would it be nice to have a solution for accessing repositories without the need of a Token (read only).

Thank you,
merlink

discussion.body:
Am I understanding correctly that you want IGitt to use pyfilesystem2 objects for handling files, or what is your aim specifically?

About read-only tokens, I'm quite sure we have token types and I think I remember us writing a token class which does read-only and doesn't need any actual token for that purpose.

After I startet working on a filesystem implementation of github (using pygithub) I was asked to create a mire flexible solution.
I think the Idea of using IGitt instead really nice.
So the idea is to have a pyfilesystem targeting a repository.
After mounting it you can directly access the files of this repo using pyfilesystem.
First step would be to create a listdir function and a file open in read only mode.
For unittesting I need to test the access of a git repo without having a token.
After testing with your dev branch I got it running by modifying code in Interface init.
But an official way would be more nicely.

title: Add a docstring
description:
Each function of the IGitt library should have the description of the function, including its parameters.

Docstring including params details should be added to the following functions. 


- [ ] Content - init, get_content, update
- [ ] Hoster - get_repo
- [ ] Installation - init
- [ ] Issue - create
- [ ] Notification - init, fetch_all
- [ ] Organization - init, create
- [ ] Repository - create_issue, create_fork, create_merge_request, create_file, _search_in_range, search_mrs, search_issues, get_permission_level
- [ ] Team - init, is_member
- [ ] User - installed_repositories

Changes should be done in functions of GitHub, GitLab, Interfaces Classes. For example if you to need add docstring to create function of Issue, you should change it in GitHubIssue, GitLabIssue, Issue.

title: Please make a new release
description:
Hi!

Thanks for excellent IGitt library. There are great features in the current master I would like to use. Could you please make a new package release on PyPI so we can use them? The version on PyPI seems to be pretty old.

Thanks a lot!

discussion.body:
Also, the current versioning is broken.

https://pypi.org/project/IGitt/0.4.1.dev20180913111540/ is a pre-release dated Sep 13, 2018 , but as you can see that is interpreted as a dev release of 0.4.1 , which was released Aug 7, 2017.

The current versions should be 0.4.2.dev... , or something else higher than 0.4.1
And there are no tags here on GitLab , and the PyPI tarball doesnt include tests, which makes it difficult to create a distro package that is verified.

https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/commit/9f5faceb3b76ca44b2988f38371f4e3f4afd5672 added automated tagging, so the next release should get a tag.

However it would be useful to have 0.4.1 tagged.

title: Search issues and mrs based on commentor for a repo object.
description: In the repository interface we have [search_mrs](https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/blob/master/IGitt/Interfaces/Repository.py#L304) and [search_issues](https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/blob/master/IGitt/Interfaces/Repository.py#L315), it would good to add another parameter `commenter` to them, which would be helpful in case we want to find all the issues or mrs commented by a user in a repository.

title: Implement rate limit management functionality
description:
We should also consider implementing the [rate limit API](https://developer.github.com/v3/rate_limit/).

Which will be helpful to check how many rate_limit is remaining and then we can avoid the rate limit exceeded error by doing a `sleep(time-interval)` method until we re-gain the rate-limit.

E.g. While using a search API we only get `30` rate_limit/minute; Now, suppose that we have a list of 1000 contributors and we have to perform a search for each. So, what we can do is, we can check if the `search_rate_limit` remaining is `1` then `sleep(60)`. [see](https://gitlab.com/coala/landing/merge_requests/57/diffs#7cbe8f429cfbabaddad71f8d9a86c83f928776cb_32_42);

Or it would be better if we could implement the whole process in IGitt itself.

title: Detect invalid usernames before performing methods
description:
Before performing some methods we should first detect if the requested username for the query is valid or not, and raise an InvalidUsername Error.

E.g. Any username not satisfying [these](https://github.com/manu-chroma/username-availability-checker/blob/master/websites.yml#L65) rules will be invalid usernames on GitHub.

But when we do:
```
>>> from IGitt.GitHub.GitHubUser import GitHubUser
>>> user = GitHubUser(GITHUB_TOKEN, 'greenkeeper[bot]')
>>> user.username
>>> 'greenkeeper[bot]'
```
It shouldn't return the user objects for invalid usernames.

Other methods to apply this functionality on, would be `GitHub.raw_search`, e.g. if the query is `commenter:sks444[bot] is:pr user:coala` should return invalid username.

And `.get() and get_response()` methods when url contain invalid usernames, etc.

title: GitHub.raw_search should return total_count parameter in the generator
description:
Search API also provides a parameter total_count([see](https://developer.github.com/v3/search/)) explicitly. It would be good to also return that parameter into the generator.

Why we need this?

1.  Suppose that I did the following search:
```
search_query = 'commenter:sks444 is:pr user:coala'
results = GitHub.raw_search(token, search_query)
```
It returns a generator of `objects of all the matched merge requests`. Now, what if I just need the total number of results? Probably I have to do `(sum(1 for _ in result)`, that would be a performance problem with the increase in the number of results.

2. As mentioned [here](https://developer.github.com/v3/search/#about-the-search-api), search API only provides max of 1000 results. But in case of `search_query = 'commenter:jayvdb is:pr user:coala'` total_count is 1720(more than 1000)
see https://api.github.com/search/issues?q=commenter:jayvdb%20is:pr%20user:coala

So, returning the total_count parameter would also help in case of more 1000 results.

discussion.body: This will require `raw_search` returns an instance of a new class which implements the `__iter__`/`__next__` methods, etc, etc.  Then the class can have extra methods like `total_count` which provide more information that was provided in the JSON.

title: Put MRs and Issues translation to init.py
description:
As we can see in GitHubRepository.py, we have the GH_* and GL* translations for Issues and MRs.

That is a general translation needed for MRs and issues. So, we can put in the init.py.

A similar case is with GitLabRepository.py.

Ref: https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/merge_requests/248#note_75779269

discussion.body:
Ah I see https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/merge_requests/248/diffs#cf7dd563983e18fc3c74e218e609c66d4fbd430d_41_41

I suggest using MAPPING instead of TRANSLATION, especially as it is mapping an enum, not a string.

However also consider that both TRANSLATION and MAPPING are inherently redundant as it is a dict.  The name should *imply* (not explicit) it is a dict and describe what it maps between (to and from).

title: Create GitHub and GitLab Merge Requests from IGitt
description:
[GitHub](https://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/#create-a-pull-request) and [GitLab](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/merge_requests.html#create-mr) Merge Requests can be created via the API. IGitt does not support this yet.

To solve this the create function should be implemented in the interface and the GitHub and GitLab implementation

title: Implement Full Set of GitHub and GitLab Issue Creation Parameters in the IGitt Interface
description:
Both [GitHub API](https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/#create-an-issue) and [GitLab API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/issues.html#new-issue) support a broader set of parameters than currently supported by the IGitt interface. The user should be able to set those parameters while creating an issue, regardless of the IGitt interface restrictions.

To solve this the create functions could call the according setters.

title: GitLab unauthenticated requests fail
description:
GitHub unauthenticated requests probably are not supported, but they do work.

```
GitHub(GitHubToken(None)).get_repo('jayvdb/flake8-putty').issues
{<GitHubIssue ....
```

However the same on GitLab results in RuntimeError

```
GitLab(GitLabPrivateToken(None)).get_repo('coala/coala-utils').issues
...
RuntimeError: ('{"message":"401 Unauthorized"}', 401)
```

discussion.body: Note that using a different token class class which doesnt return the token is not sufficient to disable authentication.

Hm, with the NoToken we're querying:

```
URL: https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/coala%2Fcoala-utils/issues
Params: {'state': 'opened', 'per_page': 100}
Headers: {'User-Agent': 'IGitt', 'Accept-Encoding': 'gzip, deflate', 'Accept': '*/*', 'Connection': 'keep-alive'}
```

which looks alright but somehow that doesn't work.
The GitLab api https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/issues.html clearly states **Every API call to issues must be authenticated** thus it is failing without token.

@ajankit2304 / MacBox7? (can you fix your username so it is consistent with GitHub.)

Could you retry with one of the GitLab APIs which dont require authentication?

This snippet works fine without token:
```
repo = GitLabRepository(GitLabPrivateToken(""), "coala/coala-utils")
repo.url
```

On the other hand this returns error `401`
```
issue = GitLabIssue(GitLabPrivateToken(""), 'coala/coala-utils', 1)
issue.state
```

Even tried with curl request: 

This gives error 401
```
curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json'  https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/gitmate%2Fopen-source%2FIGitt/issues/1 | json_pp
```

whereas this gives the desired result
```
curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json'  -H 'PRIVATE-TOKEN: <YOUR-PRIVATE-TOKEN>'  https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/gitmate%2Fopen-source%2FIGitt/issues/1 | json_pp
```

So for GitLab we need to use '' instead of None for unauthenticated?

I think we need a nicer consistent way to make unauthenticated requests, and consistent exceptions for when authentication is required.
Well yes, None results in a `TypeError` for GitLab however in case of GitHub None and " both work perfectly fine.

It looks like this has become less usable now for GitHub.

title: Use POST and DELETE instead of PATCH for setting labels on GitHub
description:
https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/labels/#add-labels-to-an-issue

otherwise the labels will be reset and that might lead to race conditions with users setting labels after GitMate has pulled the latest issue information/the webhook arrived and before the bot sets the labels.

We should also recheck if there's anything equivalent on GitLab but IIUC there isn't and we'll have to live with it.

discussion.body:
* [x]  Understand how the file works
* [x]  Understand how setting labels works
* [x]  Fix how labels works
* [x]  Try
* [x]  Write tests

This issue was solved by [commit fa3f12b3](https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/merge_requests/204/diffs?commit_id=3700847308cadb08b448c6fa7c7e8f96f67b8b73):

```
@labels.setter
    def labels(self, value: Set[str]):
       """
        Sets the labels to the given set of labels.

        :param value: A set of label texts.
        """
        # Only if self.data is populated we actually save a request here
        if 'labels' in self.data and value == self.labels:
            return  # No need to patch

        self.data = patch(self._token, self._url, {'labels': list(value)})

        for label in list(self.labels - set(value)):
            # Iteratetively removes Labels which are not to be set anymore
            delete(self._token, self._url+'/labels/'+label)

        self.data = post(self._token,
                         self._url+'/labels',
                         list(set(value) - self.labels))
```


Yet we have decide not to use the changes, since after the changes, all former labels are being overwritten as soon as new labels are being set.

The right functionallity would be the one of an `+=` operator. A `set` doesn't support the operator by default. Implementation would be a lot of effort, thats wy we've decided to drop this for now.

title: search_mrs and search_issues don't define state correctly
description:
In IGitt.Interfaces.Repository, the functions [search_mrs](https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/blob/master/IGitt/Interfaces/Repository.py#L265) and [search_issues](https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/blob/master/IGitt/Interfaces/Repository.py#L276) have state as an optional str, whereas now we use MergeRequestStates and IssueStates, this leads to failures in Python 3.5, as shown below:
![Screen_Shot_2018-01-10_at_9.54.32_PM](/uploads/3cc48288ba20c91669b9190473b27b38/Screen_Shot_2018-01-10_at_9.54.32_PM.png)

Similarly, other parameters should be `datetime` objects, and not `datetime.date` as currently.

I have a fix ready for this in [nibnalin/hotfix](https://gitlab.com/nibnalin/IGitt/commits/hotfix), I'll clean it up and make a PR if Python 3.5 support is expected. If not, the library still works fine with Python 3.6(a bit of a surprise however) and this issue may be closed.

title: add comment for cryptography explicit dependency
description:
see linked discussion
Opened by @sils

discussion.body:
The contributors most likely able to help are:

@meetmangukiya

@meetmangukiya @nkprince007 , can the problem mentioned be made public?  If so, this can probably be a GCI task.  If you think so, please label and I'll pick it up this time, or next pass in a few days.

The problem mentioned is related to https://gitlab.com/gitmate/open-source/IGitt/blob/master/requirements.txt#L3-4

`cryptography` is an explicit dependency for `PyJWT`. `GitHubJsonWebToken` requires `RSA-256` algorithms which depend on `cryptography`. 

However, `PyJWT` doesn't come bundled with `cryptography`. So, installing `cryptography` as an external dependency enables the use of `RSA-256` algorithms required.

title: Support conditional requests for github
description: https://developer.github.com/v3/#conditional-requests we're being rate limited.

discussion.body: I'm not so sure if this helps us too much with GitMate, we should do it anyway but we do have a lot of different requests.

@sils I managed to tweak the http requests in `_fetch_all_github`  from `Github/__init__.py`. A working prototype is https://dpaste.de/ton5 and its output is https://dpaste.de/oVPF

##### Understanding output
The first request returns 200 with data and the subsequent requests return 304 with cached data.

##### Implementation overview
`Url_ETag_Map = {}` ,  A map of url -> ETag is created to store the latest ETag for a given url.
`Etag_Data_Map = {}`,  A map of ETag -> data is created to store the response text for a given ETag. This is later used to fetch cached data for a given ETag.
So, the idea is to store the ETag received after making the very first http request to Github and then use this ETag for subsequent requests. Also update the ETag is case it changes.

Can we use this approach. Thoughts?

Could the data be cached by a decorator so that I don't have to care about
this from the outside?

@sils Um I am not sure. We need to add `If-None-Match` to headers before making the http requests and then we process the response. We created `_fetch_all_github` utility to do the behind the scene processing on behalf of various http methods. So it makes sense that caching should go with the same utility, as it's something being used by all methods?
@sils The patch https://dpaste.de/doap makes it more clear

Is the `writable_repositories` used by corobo a candidate for this?  If so, I'd love it as it would mean corobo could have several plugins that all fetch `writable_repositories` , rather than having multiple plugins trying to share that data to avoid a costly reloading of it.

title: Autodeploy to PYPI
description:
Environment variables PYPIPW and PYPIUSER are already available in the CI runners, just use them with

```
pip3 install twine wheel
python3 setup.py sdist bdist_wheel
twine upload dist/* -u "$PYPIUSER" -p "$PYPIPW"
```

in the CI. (First adjust version number with date though, I think actually setuptols can do that on its own.)
